106643: Savage Thallid.author: ICEFANG13
106643: Savage Thallid.text_parsed:
This fella is very impressive. I have to say I wasn't sure if I wanted him in or not in my Fungus deck.

Well lets see, the mana cost to power/toughness is fair like it used to be. There are a few things that are killer to me

1, his toughness is too low, I mean I do want a Savage Thallid to beat with, but at 4/3 I think he would be a lot better. As it stands quite a bit of mass removal is -2/2 damage/etc.

2, at five he just doesn't have the ability you want. It would be overall better I think to have his ability switched with Thallid Germinator, at the start you can protect a lot of different units with the regeneration and later pump what you want to be 'savage'

3, his ability is somewhat narrow, usually the biggest problem for most Saproling decks is board sweeps, as said before, quite a bit are either 2 damage, or don't allow regeneration. Usually Thallid Germinator can sac a sap and save the creature without tapping it (if it 'died') Germinator can also protect saps, if you have a lot, and other players creatures if you wanted/needed to.

4, usually you will have to sac a lot of saps to regen some of your creatures from a large board wiper, that's why I use Wrap in Vigor, it can be kinda dead, but it also can just switch the game from draw to complete win.

Lastly (which this one is kinda personal not as much fact), I dislike Fungus at 5 CMC and above, you just can't draw them at the beginning or you'll get overrun (other than Mycoloth, but I hate that op-ish card its not really a fungas) and Sporoloth Ancient (he is a little on both sides, if you have a good field, then its much better, if you don't then he won't be helping you out much)

Alright of a card, not at all bad, but I could see it being much better in a Naya power five deck, 2 of 5

Each Time Spiral card was an homage to at least one previously printed card.

The card references Flowstone Strike; this spellshaper turns any card in your hand into one! Flowstone was a kind of magically infused substance that could be shaped by powerful beings like liquid and then made harder than steel. 106654: Temporal Isolation.author: nemokara
106654: Temporal Isolation.text_parsed:
Currently rated at above a 4.1, I don't agree that this is underrated. Yes, it's a solid pacifism effect. The flash and damage prevention (including non-combat damage) are very nice bonuses to have, and at no extra mana cost (I would have expected such a combination to cost 3 mana, especially at common).

That being said, there are many creatures with strong effects and abilities that you do not need/want to attack with, as well as creatures with "when this creature attacks" triggered abilities that don't require damage to be dealt (Titans, anyone?) and which you can do nothing about since you probably can't block them. Those are some pretty big blind spots for this card, especially since the whole point of including it in a deck would be to neutralize most creatures you'd expect to see.

There are also some flavor issues for this card when you control other creatures with shadow. To some people that might not matter, but IMO it's a strike against it.
106654: Temporal Isolation.text_posted:
Currently rated at above a 4.1, I don't agree that this is underrated. Yes, it's a solid pacifism effect. The flash and damage prevention (including non-combat damage) are very nice bonuses to have, and at no extra mana cost (I would have expected such a combination to cost 3 mana, especially at common). 

That being said, there are many creatures with strong effects and abilities that you do not need/want to attack with, as well as creatures with "when this creature attacks" triggered abilities that don't require damage to be dealt (Titans, anyone?) and which you can do nothing about since you probably can't block them. Those are some pretty big blind spots for this card, especially since the whole point of including it in a deck would be to neutralize most creatures you'd expect to see. 

There are also some flavor issues for this card when you control other creatures with shadow. To some people that might not matter, but IMO it's a strike against it.

106654: Temporal Isolation.author: Corey_bayoudragonfly
106654: Temporal Isolation.text_parsed:
I think it's also important to note that this can be useful on your own creatures as well.
1 Creatures with 'when this creature attacks and isn't blocked': Bone Dancer, Orcish Squatters, Kukemssa Pirates, Ophidian... there several creatures that would benefit non-stupidly from this, and most of them don't get to assign combat damage when activating their effects anyway. (Merchant Ship... ha!)
2 Creatures with 'when this creature attacks': here, it's creatures whose effects you'd like to get, but which might be killed afterwards, or whose effects you'd just like to guarantee each turn: Alaborn Cavalier, Cho-Arrim Bruiser, Copperhorn Scout, Annihilator effects, conceivably Geist of Saint Traft, &c.
In a deck that cared about some of the above, Temporal Isolation would serve two purposes.

106657: Pull from Eternity.author: A3Kitsune

Get back any card that's removed from the game when you use it, any card you lost due to cascade, anything essential your opponent exiled, whatever you need and have lost. Works best in Green/White, although works in Blue/White and Black/White as well.

Edit: yea Tanaka348, I guess I missed the bit about Cascade returning the exiled cards to your library. You can still play this while the Cascade is resolving to put any card you want into your graveyard.
Also, I forgot about it burying Suspended cards. It also burys anything of your opponent's that is temporaraly or non-permanently exiled, and can do so as a react to the card about to re-enter play. And it burys Imprinted cards.

106657: Pull from Eternity.author: Argyris
106657: Pull from Eternity.text_parsed: You cannot cast anything while cascade is resolving, because you don't have priority. The only thing you _might_ be able to do has to do with paying additional costs of the spell that you decide to play as cascade resolves, but that gets to be so convoluted, it isn't worth formulating a way to do it. Also, remember, if you pull an imprinted card, it is no longer imprinted. That can be good or bad.

106657: Pull from Eternity.author: willpell
106657: Pull from Eternity.text_parsed: I'm surprised they didn't write this as "Put target suspended card into its owner's graveyard" in order to stop it from breaking with things like Time Spiral (the spell) and Restock. With one Azorius Chancery, five Islands and a little luck, you could Time Spiral a theoretically limitless number of times in one turn before you finally drew a hand which didn't have a Spiral and a Pull in it. With Foresight, this could be made even more efficient.

106657: Pull from Eternity.author: DarthParallax
106657: Pull from Eternity.text_parsed:
The Regrowth of the Exile Zone.

Riftsweeper shouldn't really count, since you need at least a soft tutor to really make it work, or some combo piece that fullstops you from being milled, like an Eldrazi Titan, in which case all that matters is that it's in your deck somewhere. Either way, Riftsweeper is too weak and narrow to warrant serious consideration.

Pull from Eternity was worth 3.5 stars back in the day, because it's like once-removed Entomb, and while the potential is great, adding more links to the chain slows you down and makes things a bit more inconsistent, harder to pull off.

Now it's worth about 5 or 6 stars. We have two Planeswalers that mess with the Exile Zone. Beware.

108788: Eternity Snare.author: Arachobia
108788: Eternity Snare.text_parsed:
Yeah its fun going on gatherer and having a laugh about the crappy cards wizards has made over the years...

...Until you go home, and you have some card with a rating lower then 1 just chilling in your card box. And you know its there, but you just can't do anyhting about it without apeparing crazy. And you're lamenting the day you opened that booster pack/theme deck/card box and have horrific memorites of the time you thought you'd try that card in a deck, just for a laugh, and the memory of drawing it and your soul fleeing your body...

It is then that you feel the chill hand of magic card hell on your soul...

108788: Eternity Snare.author: Aquillion
108788: Eternity Snare.text_parsed:
Forget about splashing other people's spot removal; just use Mind Control, which costs one less, works on more creatures, can remove a blocker, and still gives you +1. Most of the time, your opponent's best creature is going to be worth more than whatever you'd draw anyway, especially since you have to pay to cast what you draw and don't have to pay extra to get a mind-controlled creature.

(And that's not even getting into the fact that mind control once cost even less as Control Magic...)

108795: Ophidian Eye.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
108795: Ophidian Eye.text_parsed:
Part of yet another cycle! This time it was 5 common enchantments that all had flash - the others are Æther Web, Feebleness,Ghitu Firebreathing and Temporal Isolation.

Right now, community rating has Ophidian Eye in the middle of the pack, and I think that's justified. Comparing this to Sleeper's Robe is fair in some cases, but keep in mind that the robe specifies "combat damage" while this one triggers off anything. It's what makes hyrule's combo work so effectively, and you could also put it on something like Plague Spitter, Jaya Ballard, Task Mage or Kumano, Master Yamabushi. Hell, even Squallmonger would work in a multiplayer situation.

108796: Fungal Reaches.author: TheWrathofShane
108796: Fungal Reaches.text_parsed:
Pros
1) Does not come into play tapped.
2) Taps for .
3) Can spend unused mana to get a reward later on.

Cons
1) Taps for colorless, could color screw you on your opening hand.
2) Not a forest or a mountain if your deck cares about that (Dungrove Elder, Howl of the Night Pack, Strata Scythe, ect.)


This is a balanced land, potential for great long term reward and providing a way to spend unused mana. The only drawback being having multiples in your opening hand as your only lands, possibly forcing a mulligan because of color issues. I recommend 2 or 3 at the most for a deck, solid land.

108796: Fungal Reaches.author: leomistico
108796: Fungal Reaches.text_parsed:
Between all storage lands, this cycle is the most powerful, I think. It comes into field untapped, and can tap for {1}. Yes, it requires actually 2 mana to put a counter on it, but I think that it's a little price to pay, in order to be able to put counters since the beginning, instead of wait for a whole turn like the old lands... Moreover, you can pay {1} from any land to get mana from this, and still be able to tap to add a counter afterward...

My Izzet Commander deck need the enemy-color version of this land!

4/5

108804: Sudden Death.author: Enchantment_Removal
108804: Sudden Death.text_parsed:
The person in the lower right of the artwork does not look enough like Teferi. Minus 4 is good enough, for those that need split second do not exceed that toughness. Blessed be Split Second.

If a card says "Shroud", then the keyword "Shroud" is called a static ability. The question of whether or not something can be targeted is answered before you could ask it. Ever since Inkwell Leviathan was on the board, it has become fact that nothing can target him. So, you can't Sudden Death Inky into a 3/7. What you might be thinking about is aiming a Sudden Death at this guy. To deal with Inky, you'll want this card and an appropriate follow-up.

108814: Divine Congregation.author: ClockworkSwordfish
108814: Divine Congregation.text_parsed: The suspend is to deter them from playing creatures. This makes this a nifty card; you get the more-expensive but more-flexible Folk Medicine effect if you want, or you can pay the cheaper mind-screw cost and get a possibly slightly-smaller life gain a bit later but be a bit safer in that time. This is the kind of cool card that marked the Time Spiral block that I wish they'd do more of now.

108817: Dreadship Reef.author: leomistico
108817: Dreadship Reef.text_parsed:
Between all storage lands, this cycle is the most powerful, I think. It comes into field untapped, and can tap for {1}. Yes, it requires actually 2 mana to put a counter on it, but I think that it's a little price to pay, in order to be able to put counters since the beginning, instead of wait for a whole turn like the old lands... Moreover, you can pay {1} from any land to get mana from this, and still be able to tap to add a counter afterward...

My Izzet Commander deck need the enemy-color version of this land!

4/5

108819: Gaze of Justice.author: NoobOfLore
108819: Gaze of Justice.text_parsed:
An obnoxiously effective card for a common.
They don't get to attack with their creatures the same turn they use this, but they get to play a land, and take out a critical threat in the same turn.
It can mess you up pretty badly, and having it come back to bite you late game, when they have more creatures to spare, is no favor to me.

If your opponent is playing this card, you need to keep the pressure on, and trade as early and often as possible.
If you do it right, they will not have the creatures to play this in the first place.

108819: Gaze of Justice.author: DoragonShinzui
108819: Gaze of Justice.text_parsed:
First off, dayum. That is some amazing art.
Second, I have no complaints about this card whatsoever. The initial casting is fair, trading offense for a single burst of removal, but the second casting is hilarious. Suddenly, another one of their beatsticks is gone. Excellent.
Third, this combos marvelously in block with Marshaling Cry. Swing with your creatures, then tap 'em after combat for mop-up. Repeat later with both spells. Viola, any major threat that isn't combat related should be removed.

108822: Phyrexian Totem.author: Arglypuff
108822: Phyrexian Totem.text_parsed:
No, all creatures have summoning sickness. A creature can only tap or attack if the permenant which it is has haste, or has been under your constant control since the beginning of your upkeep. These totems do not have haste. If you play this totem, and then immediately turn him into a negator, then he can neither tap to add mana, nor attack.

It's honestly not that complicated. Try READING THE RULES AND KNOWING HOW TO PLAY MAGIC.
108822: Phyrexian Totem.text_posted:

It's honestly not that complicated. Try READING THE RULES AND KNOWING HOW TO PLAY MAGIC.

108822: Phyrexian Totem.author: Hovercraft
108822: Phyrexian Totem.text_parsed:
Wow you guys are dumb. Ok so this what you play this card with : Not in aggro decks, ever. You play this in a deck, usually as a 2-3 of, that plays Dust Bowl, The Abyss, something with very heavy disruption in there like Pox when you absolutely do not want to play any creatures. It is good because it dodges cards like Innocent Blood and Smallpox. you play this in the same deck as Chimeric Idol, for the same reason. You can Dark Ritual this, it is not a creature, and then tap it for mana to play Duress, or whatever.. you cannot attack the turn this enters play, were it then to become a creature right away.. but on subsequent turns, even if it has not been a creature yet ,can attack. Similarly, Mishra's factory can come into play, tap for mana like a land, or you can activate it as a blocker. You cannot tap it for its self-pump ability on your opponent's turn directly it comes into play, but you can still block and activate it as a creature albeit as a 2/2. On subsequent turns you can tap it for its self pump ability.. assign it as a blocker, then after your opponent as assigned his blocker, before combat damage is dealt, tap your factory to pump itself.

Phyrexian Totem is good for HIDING. 'Peek' with Duress, or some other card that lets you see their hand. Are they packing heat? Coast is clear? smash their face for 5 damage. Use in conjunction with Funeral Charm . there are not many decks that play him now, but in the future there may be, Pox is one lower tier deck that plays him

108823: Think Twice.author: JaxsonBateman
108823: Think Twice.text_parsed:
From the current rating and the comments, this card seems to be very underrated. A 2 mana cycle is fine, and because it's instant speed you can save your mana for counter magic, then draw a card at EOT if you didn't need to.

Being able to then cycle it *again* for 3 mana is fantastic - same situation; you can easily leave counter mana up, then if you didn't need it, get your card advantage.

It's a 4/5 IMO. And I'm hoping to see it back in Innistrad.

108830: Greenseeker.author: Mode
108830: Greenseeker.text_parsed:
I like this card for two reasons:
1. As opposed to Silverglade Pathfinder it's a one-drop.
2. Its activated ability is based on the tutor card Lay of the Land, therefore you don't get any card disadvantage from using it. It's similar to having "Basic landcycling " on one card in your hand.

It might even be useful in Madness decks. It's not a Wild Mongrel of course, yet this could also find use to reduce the amount of lands in the deck. It's a risky move though in case it gets hosed.

108830: Greenseeker.author: hansede
108830: Greenseeker.text_parsed:
Greenseeker is a fantastic card to have in a ressurection deck.

Turn 1: Play Greenseeker
Turn 2: Discard the fattest creature in your hand, grab an extra land
Turn 3: Use Animate Dead to bring your fattie into play

The last two times I played my ressurection deck I had a turn 3 Teneb, The Harvester and a turn 3 Plated Slagwurm, both of which quickly won their respective games and all of which was facilitated by the innocent looking Greenseeker.

108830: Greenseeker.author: Internet_decks_lame
108830: Greenseeker.text_parsed:
A very decent 1 cmc creature that can accelerate many different style of decks. From the first glance most would assume animator. And well it does serve as an effecient tool in the such, I would pour a little more thought into this card. Usually 1 cmc cards (being a creature that is) will not usually have game turning effects, and most highly rated 1 drops even fail if drawn in the later stages of a game, and sometimes will be just as bad as top decking a land. But even while not supporting the animator deck and pitching oh... Iona, Shield of Emeria to re-animate in the same or following turn for the likely concede from your opponent... It may serve as good support for a creature likeKnight of the Reliquary, and perhaps other cards that may feed from lands like Horn of Greed. But if we continue to examine... Landfall becomes that much more interesting, along with madness as well. But at the simplest glance, there is no card disadvantage, and for those who may believe there is some kind of disadvantage here, well it can easily be shifted into advantage. And lastly, every magic player, from veterans to newbies have all experienced mana problems which always result in unpleasant experiences, and any card that allows you to fetch lands and thin your deck is more then worthy of a second glance. And maybe its just me... but any basic land? Not restricted to only forests? Hmmmm... not sure if the name Greenseeker was the right choice...

5/5

108830: Greenseeker.author: Missile_Penguin
108830: Greenseeker.text_parsed:
Each Time Spiral card was an homage to at least one previously printed card.

The card references Lay of the Land; this spellshaper turns any card in your hand into one! During Time Spiral, the Greenseekers were sect of withered elves wandering the barren landscapes of Dominaria seeking plant life. From the flavor text, Freyalise, who can be seen on many cards such as Planeswalker's Favor, was a green planeswalker heralded as a goddess to many of the races of Dominaria throughout the Magic storyline; Skyshroud Forest is a displaced elvish haven that was transferred from Rath during the events of Planeshift. Freyalise and Eladamri, Lord of Leaves located the displaced forest in the mountains of Keld, where they were shielded from the events of Apocalypse, as depicted on the card Skyshroud Blessing.

108832: Call to the Netherworld.author: yyukichigai
108832: Call to the Netherworld.text_parsed:
Its plain effect is worse than Raise Dead, but it's countered by the fact that Madness allows you to play it at any time. Instant-speed graveyard card grabs aren't the most useful thing in the world, but they aren't bad. Also, it's worth noting that this card can return more than just mono-colored creatures, e.g. you could return your Psychatog, if you were the sort of sick deviant person to be playing with a Psychatog in the first place.

@djflo: As far as I understand, because the discard would be a cost both cards are considered discarded immediately with the same "timestamp", meaning you decide which one gets placed in the graveyard first. Once that happens, then replacement effects (e.g. Madness) come into play. The replacement effect places the spell on the stack "the next time you could play an instant," i.e. AFTER the cards have already been discarded, meaning that yes, you could bring the black creature you just discarded back to your hand. I think. I'm not a DCI Judge.

108839: Saltcrusted Steppe.text_posted: If you've got a mana-engine going (especially one with land-untapping), these storage lands could be used as a place to stoe unused mana. Even better if you are running [autocard]Doubling Season[/autocard].

108839: Saltcrusted Steppe.author: ThinkOriginal
108839: Saltcrusted Steppe.text_parsed: I was looking through my older cards from Timespiral, and after reading this card carefully, I realized something about these store-lands. Their third ability doesn't cause them to tap, and you can use the colored mana it produces from the the storage counters to tap and add another storage counter afterwards. After the initial mana investment to get a charge counter or (not difficult at all with any sort of ramp), this can become a handy and non-bank-breaking way for a deck to ramp up with other colors, especially if you like fiddling with mana-fixers.

108839: Saltcrusted Steppe.author: Missile_Penguin
108839: Saltcrusted Steppe.text_parsed:
Each Time Spiral card was an homage to at least one previously printed card.

This card is part of a five-card cycle referencing the various kinds of "storage lands;" the first were in Fallen Empires (Icatian Store, et al) then tried again in Mercadian Masques (Subterranean Hangar, et al). This cycle became easily the most successful, finding a way to make the 'storage' part of the land less-clunky, promoting some entrants in this cycle to appear in tournament-caliber constructed decks.

108841: Trespasser il-Vec.author: Missile_Penguin
108841: Trespasser il-Vec.text_parsed:
Every card in Time Spiral was a throwback to at least one previously printed card.

This card references Dauthi Marauder and Thalakos Drfters. Likely, the "discard for effect" ability was favored here to help facilitate spells with Madness, an ability that allows discarded cards to be cast anyway, which was brought back and focused in black.

During Tempest block, on the plane of Rath, the Vec were one of the tribes of corporeal beings waging a rebellion against the Phyrexian dictator, Volrath. When the entire plane was overlaid onto Dominaria during Planeshift, all the corporeal tribes were forced into a shadowy aether-world, demonstrated by each Vec, Kor, and Dal card having shadow in Time Spiral block.

You can see a desire for physicality in both the Drifter and Augur il-Vec.

108850: Drudge Reavers.author: Zaneshift
108850: Drudge Reavers.text_parsed:
Well to judge this card you first need to take a look at its context: it's a skeleton. Every skeleton is compared to Drudge Skeletons, so just look at it in that light. On the one hand, it's twice the cost; on the other, it's got twice the power. Since it has regenerate the minor toughness difference is fairly inconsequential. Flash is interesting, but only all that useful if you have a lot of responses they you need open mana on your opponents' turns for. It's also quite useful in that it makes for an interesting roundabout removal spell if you cast it blocking a big creature of your opponent's that has little toughness, since you can regenerate it immediately. Rather situational, and not the best if you're going skeleton tribal where you'd be better off with more drudge clones, but it has enough uses for a 4/5 in my book. Actually, if you have Death Baron, or maybe Bad Moon or some other rare boost for skeletons, it could fill a creature removal role quite well. Just make sure, as with any regenerating creature, to leave some open mana; if you don't use regenerate then it's at best a 1.5/5.

I almost went and commented on my comment.
I should pay attention, I'm Zaneshift. XD
Just wanted to add that it's basically a Phyrexian Monitor with Flash rather than 2 toughness, which is a pretty nice tradeoff. Also, Death Baron makes it a "destroy target attacking creature" spell with the deathtouch addition, which is pretty nice.

108850: Drudge Reavers.author: DarthParallax
108850: Drudge Reavers.text_parsed: This would be excellent if, instead of Regeneration, it had Fast Regeneration. Name it exactly that, and make the rules reminder text read to do exactly what you want "Fast Regeneration" to do: Be like Regeneration except that you can activate it ''in response'', at instant speed, and it will work like you want it to, rather than the way normal Regeneration works, where you have to activate it before you know what your creature might be getting into. Fast Regeneration to me is in some sense like Double Strike: An ability that should totally be adopted as an Evergreen Keyword, that I designed on the spot in answer to "How do I make this good ability better?" I would be a lot more okay if they brought Shroud back, next to Hexproof. I'm not saying have an overload of Regeneration or Shroud-- I'm saying that some of the cards that would have been Regenerators are now Fast Regenerators and some of the cards that would have been Hexproof now have Shroud- you would end up with a pretty small amount of Double Strike, Hexproof, and Fast Regeneration, and still plenty of First Strike, Shroud, and Regenerate.

108858: Dream Stalker.author: remnant_phoenix
108858: Dream Stalker.text_parsed:
I think that this is an overlooked card that is more useful that most people realize. I have mono-blue bounce deck and I run a full set of these. I combo this card off of Sage of Epityr, turning the drawback of this card into an advantage: I can have a 1/5 blocker on turn 2 and I get to replay the Sage, which is good for setup. I also use this card in the later game to bounce Reality Acid, which is fun.

This can combo well off of any creatures that have "when it comes into play effects," especially cheaper ones. For the "bounce your own permanent" ability, most decks would be better served by Vedalken Mastermind, but if you need the extra toughness for blocking, I think this card is actually the better way to go. Or, if you have the room in your deck, run both.
108858: Dream Stalker.text_posted:

108858: Dream Stalker.author: Internet_decks_lame
108858: Dream Stalker.text_parsed:
Here is a creature that potentially offers impressive delay, and can also combo quite well with many different "enters the battlefield" permanent's effects. Also, toughness 5 is nothing to scoff at, and must be seriously considered. Most cases to remove a creature with toughness 5 it will usually take 2 cards, unless an opponent is desperate enough to waste a STP or path to exile. And if thats the case... Card well played. Take a format like legacy for example, where creatures like tarmogoyf run rampant. Well the goyf usually tapers out at 4/5 maybe 3/4. Very rarily it will make 5 or better on the power. Also the aggro red & green that tries to come with turn 1 goblin guide equipped with rancor... casted by either elvish spirit guide or simian spirit guide again the toughness 5 puts that to a halt fairly quickly as well. Any aggro style deck has a lot of problems with 4 toughness creatures, never mind 5... and if you think about it, with all the new power creeps being made and how easily a lot of 3 cmc creatures are reaching 4 toughness or better now, well there is a reason for it. This guy is 2 cmc with 5 toughness. Hmmm... an aggro nightmare which possibly links into combos...

5/5

108860: Molten Slagheap.author: leomistico
108860: Molten Slagheap.text_parsed:
Between all storage lands, this cycle is the most powerful, I think. It comes into field untapped, and can tap for {1}. Yes, it requires actually 2 mana to put a counter on it, but I think that it's a little price to pay, in order to be able to put counters since the beginning, instead of wait for a whole turn like the old lands... Moreover, you can pay {1} from any land to get mana from this, and still be able to tap to add a counter afterward...

My Izzet Commander deck need the enemy-color version of this land!

4/5

108860: Molten Slagheap.author: Missile_Penguin
108860: Molten Slagheap.text_parsed:
Nearly every single Time Spiral card was an homage to at least one previously printed card.

This card is part of a five-card cycle referencing the various kinds of "storage lands;" the first were in Fallen Empires (Icatian Store, et al) then tried again in Mercadian Masques (Subterranean Hangar, et al). This cycle became easily the most successful, finding a way to make the 'storage' part of the land less-clunky, promoting some entrants in this cycle to appear in tournament-caliber constructed decks.
108860: Molten Slagheap.text_posted:
[b]Nearly every single [i]Time Spiral[/i] card was an homage to at least one previously printed card.[/b]

This card is part of a five-card cycle referencing the various kinds of "storage lands;" the first were in [i]Fallen Empires[/i] ([autocard]Icatian Store[/autocard], et al) then tried again in [i] Mercadian Masques[/i] ([autocard]Subterranean Hangar[/autocard], et al). This cycle became easily the most successful, finding a way to make the 'storage' part of the land less-clunky, promoting some entrants in this cycle to appear in tournament-caliber constructed decks.

Grave Peril destroys a creature that comes into play on a future turn.

108894: Mindstab.author: Fanaticmogg
108894: Mindstab.text_parsed:
This was printed in the same block as Damnation. Give your opponent a choice: Either over-extend to minimize the effect of the discard and lose all their cards to the combination of boardwipe and discard, or hold back so you get maximum value out of Mindstab while being able to save your board-wipe.

A control deck won't be worried about the boardwipe, but the discard will still hit them hard. They might counter it, but then they've tapped some of their lands and you haven't, so you can force through a threat or something.

108898: Zealot il-Vec.author: TopRomen
108898: Zealot il-Vec.text_parsed:
Uhm. Wow. This guy deserves a BIT of a higher rating than it has now. O.o

This card is SOLID in white. The only types of cards they have that ping rely on hitting attacking or blocking creatures... Except this guy, who has great evasion, and deals his redirect damage even before first strike. This is good in white beat down if it relies on creatures. It deals direct damage to any enemy creatures your opponent controls, and they can't protect important little guys by not attacking or blocking with them (as they can with other white cards). NO-ONE IS SAFE!

Strangly, this card has aged well. Since shadow isn't very common anymore, these guys will likely always go unblocked, and give you a way to block enemy shadow creatures. And if your opponent manages to block your Zealot...?

One last thing before I finally go away; I love the flavor with the art. It's really cool how you can see that he is in the shadow realm, but he throws his dagger thing and it like *poof* enters the real world with a shock wave and goes into someone's jugular. AWESOME.

So he is basically a white pinger with a few restrictions instead of just tapping... That is really pretty good. 4/5 from me.

108898: Zealot il-Vec.author: Missile_Penguin
108898: Zealot il-Vec.text_parsed:
Every card in Time Spiral was a throwback to at least one previously printed card.

This card references Farrel's Zealot as well as Soltari Guerillas. During Tempest block, on the plane of Rath, the Vec were one of the tribes of corporeal beings waging a rebellion against the Phyrexian dictator, Volrath. When the entire plane was overlaid onto Dominaria during Planeshift, all the corporeal tribes were forced into a shadowy aether-world, demonstrated by the Vec, Kor, and Dal all having shadow in Time Spiral block.

108898: Zealot il-Vec.author: Fadingstar
108898: Zealot il-Vec.text_parsed:
I completely understand the low rating of this card due to its cost and power. However, in my Lin Sivvi, Defiant Hero EDH deck, this guy is an all-star. Being essentially unblockable and dealing direct damage to creatures isn't something you see that often in white, so the 3 cmc seems a bit more "fair" from that perspective. As mentioned before, his utility is realized when equipped with anything granting deathtouch (Gorgon Flail, Basilisk Collar).

Though looking at the art I like to think he's throwing a Quietus Spike at someone. In my deck he usually is.

108900: Icatian Crier.author: HuntingDrake
108900: Icatian Crier.text_parsed:
@Jdrawer:
Townsfolk is a defunct creature type. Twelve Townsfolk were printed, but they've all since lost that type. Oddly, none of them became Citizens. (http://magiccards.info/query?s=issue&q=ct:townsfolk+-e:uh)
"Citizen" only ever appeared on Icatian Town, and probably should've been eradicated in favor of Human or Soldier. But then Time Spiral came along and revived it for nostalgia's sake (with Icatian Crier and Sarpadian Empires, Vol. VII).
The real facepalm moment is when you realize both creature types originated in Fallen Empires.
108900: Icatian Crier.text_posted:

He's a knight. Curves beautifully with the M11 lord. Knights are silly. They've never really been a full Tier 1 deck, cuz they've been just mildly sprinkled throughout Magic's history, but they are probably the number 1 budget deck build a long-time gamer can make.

White Knight -> Paladin En-vec -> Cavalry Master -> Knight Exemplar -> Mirran Crusader...and they just keep getting stupider.

playtest name: Ride of the Rohirrim

But, a few things I don't know:

2. When it hits the graveyard, can you use Colfenor's Urn?


Can anyone help me out on that?

108904: Foriysian Totem.author: kiseki
108904: Foriysian Totem.text_parsed:
This card works for me.
I nearly always have a 1-drop on the third turn so I only lose two mana, it ramps me into 6 mana quicker, and when my red deck has played out it's whole hand, then I get to attack with a 4/4 trample.
Sure, I could use felwar stone and get lucky anytime an opponent is using red, but the additional flexibility this allows makes this worth it.
Also, it amuses me to no end that this is an homage to a card with one of the most ridiculous creature names ever: Two-Headed Giant of Foriys (Say it out loud if you don't get it)

108904: Foriysian Totem.text_parsed:
Every card in Time Spiral was a throwback to at least one previously printed card.

This card is part of a cycle of 3 casting cost mana-producing artifacts that turn into creatures which cannot be reprinted due to the Reserved list. This card is referencing Two-Headed Giant of Foriys (pronounced like the 'four-eyes' on the two heads). The others in this cycle include Chronatog Totem, Phyrexian Totem, Thunder Totem, and Weatherseed Totem.

108915: Rift Bolt.author: Falgorn
108915: Rift Bolt.text_parsed:
@DarthParallax:

When you remove the last time counter from a suspended card, you cast it without paying its mana cost. So the opponent can counter it like any other spell. They can also use Nix on it. Actually, the Future Signt Pacts and cards with suspend were the reason for Nix's existence.

As for Rift Bolt itself, it's a perfect addition for red storm decks. Moreover, as has already been mentioned, by suspending it, you can quite often delay your opponent from casting a creature for a turn, which can be a really useful tempo advantage if you 're trying to combo FTW or if you're playing a con-trolling deck (pun intended).

108915: Rift Bolt.author: LordRandomness
108915: Rift Bolt.text_parsed: Suspend it the turn before you plan to sacrifice Quest for Pure Flame. Leaves you with all your mana to cast other burn and adds 6 damage to the tally. Highly painful, and Rift Bolt is better than lightning bolt in several other situations too.
108915: Rift Bolt.text_posted: Suspend it the turn before you plan to sacrifice [autocard]Quest for Pure Flame[/autocard]. Leaves you with all your mana to cast other burn and adds 6 damage to the tally. Highly painful, and Rift Bolt is better than lightning bolt in several other situations too.

108915: Rift Bolt.author: DarthParallax
108915: Rift Bolt.text_parsed:
actually...I believe this is a Lightning Bolt that is uncounterable...or am I wrong about suspend?
Not STRICTLY better of course, but better than 'as good as'! Compared to Lightning Bolt, and even coming anywhere near that close to 'better than' makes this shockingly good. pun entirely intended.
this is like getting the crap beat out of you by Super Saiyan Goku, BUT YOU SURVIVED! wait no...Goku was too nice to kill...make that Super Saiyan Vegeta-AND YOU'RE STILL ALIVE! amazing. 3/20/11

EDIT: OK, so I knew nothing about Magic in 2011 :p

In one year, almost to the day, I've seen a lot more cards, built a lot more decks, and generally gotten better at Magic and evaluating cards and strategies. My new evaluation of this card is that, at 3 mana and sorcery speed for an effect that is fine at 2 mana and instant speed...

Always pay the Suspend Cost on Suspend cards. Always. Cyclical Evolution looks better once you realize it's two Giant Growths for about twice the cost of 1. In other words, fair.
Pardic Dragon is a Sad Panda, and Greater Gargadon is probably the best Suspend after Ancestral Vision.

108915: Rift Bolt.author: Minus_Prime

Then it just burns the opponent for 3 having already kept the path clear for a pair of Spark Elementals or something. In that sense it's like a discounted Searing Blaze, coincidentally the next spell I plan to cast.

108926: Plunder.author: scumbling1
108926: Plunder.text_parsed: Targeted land destruction with Suspend is about the worst idea since Banding. You play a LD spell to keep the opponent off a color or critical amount of mana, and thus gain an advantage in tempo. If you wait four turns for the stupid thing to go off, your opponent has probably had ample time to find more mana and drop his hand. This is way too slow to be anything but terrible.

108926: Plunder.author: Deepfried-Owls
108926: Plunder.text_parsed:
That's why it's pivotal to use something that removes counters for a low mana cost or simple taps.

Land Destruction is too expensive to use without accelerators anyways so by turn 4-6 when you're playing LD, this card is completely fine. Played at turn 2, you smack a land at turn 6 if not earlier.

If anything else, the opponent wastes time and mana on this pesky little piece of crap.

108926: Plunder.author: Cheza
108926: Plunder.text_parsed:
Land destruction was increased from 3 mana to 4 mana to prevent a total lockdown, if you're going first and use a mana acceleration on turn 1 (f.e Sol Ring). In this way, you were able to destroy the only land your opponent controls.

This card however is awful. Even with a Jhoira's Timebug or Rift Elemental, you can't reduce this to an acceptable delay. So either should they have reduced the suspend counters by 1, allowing some turn 3 tricks with Fury Charm (that wouldn't be that hard for a 2:1 ratio) or they should have limited it to nonbasic land destruction instead.

108930: Calciform Pools.author: BegleOne
108930: Calciform Pools.text_parsed:
These lands are great. The best storage lands, I think.

They don't come into play tapped and they can tap for a colorless. That means that you're not behind the curve if you just need the colorless. That is huge.

They don't need to tap to remove a counter. If you really need a blue or white, you spend two mana of a different color to tap it, add a counter and then remove the counter in the same turn.

And, they make mana of two different colors at the time you need them. Lots of fun.

108930: Calciform Pools.author: Zylo-
108930: Calciform Pools.text_parsed:
This card is a lot more powerful than people are giving it credit for. Play with 4 of these in a blue/white deck with some big creatures and spells and then come back to re-rate this... Massive mana ramping and it comes in untapped. There will always be many turns in a game when you have one extra mana at the end of an opponents turn and this lets you save it all up to dump heavy spells or cast "X" for lots. If you play this early you can mana ramp faster than green.....

Very under rated card. If you play Blue/White, buy a playset for yourself! You'll be glad you did. One of my favorite cards.

108930: Calciform Pools.author: leomistico
108930: Calciform Pools.text_parsed:
Between all storage lands, this cycle is the most powerful, I think. It comes into field untapped, and can tap for {1}. Yes, it requires actually 2 mana to put a counter on it, but I think that it's a little price to pay, in order to be able to put counters since the beginning, instead of wait for a whole turn like the old lands... Moreover, you can pay {1} from any land to get mana from this, and still be able to tap to add a counter afterward...

My Izzet Commander deck need the enemy-color version of this land!

4/5

108930: Calciform Pools.author: jonrds
108930: Calciform Pools.text_parsed:
Oh, wow this is underrated. Whats the mana cost on mana leak? {1}{U}. What can this tap for? {1}. Just keep this and an island open during your opponent's turn, threatening a counterspell, then at the end of his turn, tap both to store a mana. Then use all that built up mana to cast a big sphinx's revelation without tapping yourself out.

Any time a land taps for 1 the turn it's played, can tap for 1 every turn, doesn't make you lose another land, and has some beneficial effect, you want to take a good look at it. This doesnt sit around tapped every turn until you specifically choose to untap it, like some of the other storage lands. It also doesnt take 3 turns to start possibly generating mana like the other cycle. That is a huge difference.

Its like they put gemstone array on a land, got rid of its mana cost, and didn't put any drawbacks on it.

108931: Thunder Totem.author: HuntingDrake
108931: Thunder Totem.text_parsed:
I guess Randy Asplund-Faith was the only Reserved-List creature artist that they couldn't dig up for Time Spiral, so they got another Randy instead.

I always felt like 3 mana was slightly steep to activate this guy. Even moreso since Glinthawk Idol's printing. But I checked the reserved list, and there are almost no other eligible white creatures (non-Legendary, non-tribal, no awkward activated abilities/upkeep costs).
-Veteran Bodyguard was put to good use as Weathered Bodyguards. (Hmm, but maybe if Academy Rector became the morph...)
-Avenging Angel is too similar to Weatherseed Treefolk, but makes a sweet Pulmonic Sliver.
-And that's it! Sidar Jabari is Legendary and became Gustcloak Cavalier. Zhalfirin Crusader is the next best option, but again, rather unwieldy. The pickings are slim.

So, it looks like it had to be Thunder Spirit. I'll admit, it does have some good nostalgia going for it.

108931: Thunder Totem.author: Aaron_Forsythe
108931: Thunder Totem.text_parsed:
Aaron’s Random Card Comment of the Day #65, 2/16/10

There’s a hidden subtheme in the design of many of the Time Spiral cycles, and that theme is the Reserve List (a list of old rare cards we’ve promised never to reprint). We felt a nostalgia set was a good venue for creating homages to cards we can’t print so that people could enjoy what those cards are capable of in new ways.

Three of the five rare Slivers are modeled after Reserved cards (Avenging Angel, Juzam Djinn, Sedge Troll), as are four of the five Maguses (Memory Jar, Mirror Universe, Cursed Scroll, Candelabra of Tawnos), and four of the six “can only be suspended” spells (Black Lotus, Ancestral Recall, Wheel of Fortune, Eureka).

All five of the uncommon mana Totems turn into Reserved creatures, including this one, which becomes Thunder Spirit. (The others become Chronatog, Phyrexian Negator, Two-Headed Giant of Foriys, and Weatherseed Treefolk).

Thunder Spirit may be the most ridiculous card on the Reserved List. It would be common today, no problem, but we can’t print it--or anything with those exact stats--again. The only thing close to as ridiculous as it is Aeolipile.

Aside on the Reserve List: I hate that it exists. Creating it in the first place was reactionary and causes me no end of grief. What I do like, however, is working for a company with integrity that will stand by its promises. So it isn’t going away, which is inconvenient but correct.

Back to the Totems… I made them, and many of them retained the homage I submitted them with (I had Zephid instead of Chronatog), but in retrospect they are absurd uncommons. Pretend you have never heard of Chronatog or Phyrexian Negator. What in the world kind of uncommon mana stone turns into a 1/2 creature that lets you skip turns as a cost to get bigger? What does that even mean? In fact, the only one of the five that I think stands on its own as a card that I wouldn’t be embarrassed to show someone today is this one, Thunder Totem. It’s ironic that the reason it feels so out of place on the Reserve List is the exact reason why it makes an okay Totem.

108931: Thunder Totem.author: GainsBanding
108931: Thunder Totem.text_parsed: I also think the reserved list is unnecessary.
108931: Thunder Totem.text_posted: I also think the reserved list is unnecessary.

108931: Thunder Totem.author: willpell
108931: Thunder Totem.text_parsed: I too hate the Reserve List; it was a stupid idea and I see no reason whatsoever not to break it.  Does anyone still care about making sure that their old collectible card remains unique?  If so, give it another 20-30 years, those people's ability to voice a complaint will eventually dissipate.  But it occurs to me that the perfect time to have ditched the Reserve List would have been when Hasbro bought Wotco; someone who knew the buyout was coming could have asked Hasbro to hand down a mandate that breaks the Reserve List, and then everyone at Wotco who was kicking themselves about the Reserve List but needed to pretend they weren't could just go "Oh well, it wasn't our decision".  If anyone else ever buys Wotco or Hasbro (not that I want that to happen by any stretch, but business is what it is), I hope the buying company gets the idea that reprinting Reserve List cards is a good investment.

108931: Thunder Totem.author: Cheza
108931: Thunder Totem.text_parsed:
@ Aaron:

I never was a great fan of cheap good flyers, since evasion often FORCES you into a specific gameplay and it forces R&D to keep up with reach. I also like strategy pc-games more, the less flying creatures they include.

In magic terms, I think a 1/1 flyer for 1 is MUCH less a problem than a 2/2 or 2/1 flyer for cmc2.

I also dislike the fact that R&D is possessed by the idea to make white the main color of flying creatures. In my opinion, this really breaks the "community" and "stand together, fall together" flavor of white, as half of your "comrades" fly above your head. So if you need to print cheap flyer, distribute them more evenly over every color... and this might lead us to the "good old days", where green had the cmc1 slot. The Thunder Spirit however, would be a wonderful black Specter.

@ the totems:
As I always said, it should be the last option to print something as an artifact, since it loses much of it's flavor. Simple effects are ok, but the more specific a card gets, the less flavorful it sounds as a colorless card. It isn't odd at all that Thunder Totem is the "best" totem in this cycle, as it is the most simple one and therefore the most acceptable one. But it still seems odd that white uses the word "thunder" in it's name and that a token can be transferred into a flying creature that it outstanding enough to have first strike as well.

108931: Thunder Totem.author: Missile_Penguin

Every card in Time Spiral was a throwback to at least one previously printed card.

This card is part of a cycle of 3 casting cost mana-producing artifacts that turn into creatures which cannot be reprinted due to the Reserved list. This card is referencing Thunder Spirit. The others in this cycle include Chronatog Totem, Phyrexian Totem, Weatherseed Totem, and Foriysian Totem.

Also, Aaron's comment's got me beat, but I shall post for consistency's sake!

108931: Thunder Totem.author: leomistico
108931: Thunder Totem.text_parsed:
@Aaron: discovering why the blue totem has such strange ability is part of what is wonderful in Magic: the discovery. Somebody can say "What the hell is this? Whatever, doesn't matter" and leave the card alone, but another person can say "Interesting ability, where it came from? Let's search...". The thrill of discovery is something that makes Magic great! However, I would have liked Zephid much more than this one, that was only good in combo with Smokestack...

@Cheeza:
"I also dislike the fact that R&D is possessed by the idea to make white the main color of flying creatures."
I don't agree with you, but for this sentence I'm totally with you! I don't understand why white should have so many flying creatures. Flying is an ability so common that sometimes it doesn't have any point... Moreover, non-angel flying creatures often seem non-natural, quite forced! White, like green, have the best creatures, so they shouldn't have evasive creatures too: white, for me, should have mid-range size Angel or Spirit creatures, like 3/3 or 4/4, not too big and not too common. I think that red has enough evasion mechanism to justify more common flying creatures, instead of white.

109671: Stronghold Overseer.author: A3Kitsune
109671: Stronghold Overseer.text_parsed: Great creature. But he's not entirely unblockable. Each color has a way to block this using cards of only it's color. Blue and Black can give a flying creature shadow, White and Blue can give a shadow creature flying, Blue can give all Slivers flying and shadow, red has a Wall that can block creatures with shadow (Wall of Diffusion) and an aura that gives flying (and cards that take away flying), and then there's Green. Green has; an aura that lets a creature block this straight out (AEther Web), a card that removes shadow (Reality Anchor), a creature that remove flying (Radjan Spirit), a creature that grants flying (Pixie Queen), creatures that can block flyers, a creature that can block creatures with shadow (Heartwood Dryad), aura that give creatures reach, and Flash Foliage.
109671: Stronghold Overseer.text_posted: Great creature. But he's not [u]entirely[/u] unblockable. Each color has a way to block this using cards of only it's color. 109671: Stronghold Overseer.author: Eved
109671: Stronghold Overseer.text_parsed:
Original Date Posted:3/3/2010 9:02:40 PM
Yes, I realize it's turn 3 and I am attacking you for 6 unblockable. That's how I see many games starting out for me. This will go great with my Dark Rituals.

Edit : WARNING, lots of ranting : Perhaps I should have said "essentially unblockable". Would that have made all of you happy? I know full well it's not entirely unblockable seeing as it can be blocked by another copy of itself. I can't believe nobody's mentioned that yet. A3Kitsune, thank you for pointing out AEther Web to everyone else here. I was wondering how long it was going to be before anyone figured out there was a card in the same set as this guy that was a direct response to him. The reason I neglected to say "essentially" when I first posted was because nobody prepares to defend against shadow decks unless someone in their playgroup uses a (very powerful shadow card such as this one or a) shadow deck. Also, to everyone naming off 2 card combos just to block it, why even bother? There is removal, mind controlling cards, and of course Lignify, etc. All of which are single card ways of dealing with this, not multiple card combos that use obscure cards that have little use. I'm in no way saying this card is bad because it can be targeted by removal, I love this card and still use it in almost every deck I make, I'm just saying that people need to stop posting ways that it can be blocked and start putting up posts with cards that have synergy with this one.

Honestly, it bugs me to change my comment, but I feel it is needed because nobody is saying anything useful about this card anymore. Also, Seedborn Muse so you can buff your creature/s or debuff your opponent's creature/s on everyone's turns.

109671: Stronghold Overseer.author: Missile_Penguin
109671: Stronghold Overseer.text_parsed:
Every card in Time Spiral was a throwback to at least one previously printed card.

This card references Flowstone Overseer. The Stronghold in it's name is a reference to Volrath's Stronghold, the seat of power for the dictator of Rath. During the planar overlay of Planeshift the stronghold and it's displaced, shadowy contents appeared in the swamps of Urborg. Later, the Phyrexian god-king Yawgmoth would be slain here, rendering it Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth (you can see the husk of the stronghold in the art.)
109671: Stronghold Overseer.text_posted:
[b]Every card in [i]Time Spiral[/i] was a throwback to at least one previously printed card.[/b]

This card references [autocard]Flowstone Overseer[/autocard]. The Stronghold in it's name is a reference to [autocard]Volrath's Stronghold[/autocard], the seat of power for the dictator of Rath. During the planar overlay of [i]Planeshift[/i] the stronghold and it's displaced, shadowy contents appeared in the swamps of [autocard]Urborg[/autocard]. Later, the Phyrexian god-king Yawgmoth would be slain here, rendering it [autocard]Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth[/autocard] (you can see the husk of the stronghold in the art.)

109673: Clockspinning.author: Link3895
109673: Clockspinning.text_parsed:
This is seriously one of the most over powered common cards I've seen. People here try to say it's so limited because of the buyback, two Memory Crystals and the buyback is free. Plus with the thousands of cards in Magic (unless you're using rules restricting to certain sets/blocks), the possibilities are endless.

I run this in a control deck set to lock down an opponent's non-blue/artifact deck, Quicksilver Fountain turns lands into Islands, Clockspinning can prevent the final part of the Fountain's ability and keep all lands islands.

While it may not use counters, Paradise Plume can get you loaded up on HP with each cast, and with free buyback it's more HP. Also goes well with Clearwater Goblet for even more HP.

It can also go good with cards like Armageddon Clock, Time Bomb, or anything else to deal worldwide damage and keep creatures under control. Decree of Silence was mentioned already, which is another great use.

Seriously, the possibilities are limitless with this one in a deck full of counters, especially with Memory Crystal.

This is seriously one of the most over powered common cards I've seen. People here try to say it's so limited because of the buyback, two [autocard]Memory Crystal[/autocard]s and the buyback is free. Plus with the thousands of cards in Magic (unless you're using rules restricting to certain sets/blocks), the possibilities are endless.

I run this in a control deck set to lock down an opponent's non-blue/artifact deck, [autocard]Quicksilver Fountain[/autocard] turns lands into Islands, Clockspinning can prevent the final part of the Fountain's ability and keep all lands islands.

While it may not use counters, [autocard]Paradise Plume[/autocard] can get you loaded up on HP with each cast, and with free buyback it's more HP. Also goes well with [autocard]Clearwater Goblet[/autocard] for even more HP.

It can also go good with cards like [autocard]Armageddon Clock[/autocard], [autocard]Time Bomb[/autocard], or anything else to deal worldwide damage and keep creatures under control. [autocard]Decree of Silence[/autocard] was mentioned already, which is another great use.

Seriously, the possibilities are limitless with this one in a deck full of counters, especially with [autocard]Memory Crystal[/autocard].

Always going to be a 4.5 star card for me.

109675: Thrill of the Hunt.author: blurrymadness
109675: Thrill of the Hunt.text_parsed:
I don't know why some of the smarter comments are being downvoted, this is almost universally weaker than other comparable spells. Being able to use it twice is nice, but it's very defensive and if your opponent calls your bluff the second time you'd use it you either waste it or he bluffed you! It's not often that two creatures (for me anyway) that are mirrored stats (1/2 fighting a 2/1 for example), and that's where this card tends to help most.

Comparable Cards:
Barkshell Blessing
Joint Assault
Prey's Vengeance

While they each have difference limitations, the total buffs on the above are +4/+4 and for *NO* additional mana commitment. This card is a total +2/+4 and is only better in very situational circumstances. Run Barkshell most of the time (if you need to buff two, or think you may need to buff the same one twice in one go, possibly due to Livewire Lash shinanigans)

Many other cards offer a straight up +4/+4 or better for the same or less cost and some restriction; but even the above show that this card is bottom of the pile, while being quite usable.

109680: Spirit Loop.author: Omenchild
109680: Spirit Loop.text_parsed:
wrong Silversky, this is what would happen

Player 1 Shocks the Mogg, and Player 2 lets it resolve.

The Mogg is dealt damage, and then in return puts his ability on the stack, but also dies.

State-based action comes first, killing the Mogg and the aura
Then the Triggered action on Spirit Loop would go on the stack
Spirit Loop Returns to Hand
THEN the Mogg's ability hits, and it deals damage.
The Spirit Loop would have to be on it when it deals the damage, NOT when the ability is put on the stack.

Lifelink wouldn't work either, because he's dead when his ability activated.

109685: Sulfurous Blast.author: Pumpkin2146
109685: Sulfurous Blast.text_parsed:
DRCCOTD #3

Sulfurous Blast: Now this is a high quality flexible card. It is similar to other red "mass removal" effects like Pyroclasm or Volcanic Fallout, but it both does more damage and has more flexibility. It isn't very useful in the red deck that is playing out weenies and using burn to get them through, but in a more controlling "bigger" version of red that wants to be using dragons and the like to kill, then this is obviously an excellent card.

It is worth remembering that you can decide to not main-phase it to have it only do 2 damage if that would be useful to you (ie. you have some 3 toughness guys you want to beat with, wait unti beginning of combat to cast it).

Also, it does damage to players as well. This make it an interesting choice in "pure" burn decks, to which the killing of creatures bit won't be nearly as relevant as a downside, although in these decks it most likely is weaker than Flamebreak in spite of the added flexibility of being able to cast it as an instant.

If this card was printed in modern sets, I think it would be a high pick in limited, sweeping effects usually are as they let you play your opponent into a trap that yields significant card advantage. It would, metagame dependant, see play in constructed also. As a pure sweeper it obviously isn't as good as cards like Day of Judgment, but it does the sweeping job for red about as well as can be expected.

109686: Pardic Dragon.author: TinGorilla
109686: Pardic Dragon.text_parsed: This card really is only useful against control decks that seek to leave all their lands untapped and counter what you play. The dragon is supposed to force them to tap their lands in an effort to keep him out of play. However, what that means is that you too will have to stop playing spells to avoid giving them a target for their counterspells, and that means that they will just be stockpiling their counters, and will likely be able to spare one for this guy.

109691: Careful Consideration.author: Wanderer25
109691: Careful Consideration.text_parsed:
I agree with Biggles that this is great in a deck built around Megrim (or now, Liliana's Caress). It doesn't even need Underworld Dreams to be a finisher. It that type of deck, it is far superior to cards like Fugue because the discard is guaranteed, which it often isn't in the late game, when hands are more likely to be empty. If you run 4x Liliana's Caress in your deck, there's a good chance you'll have two of them out by the time you play this. I've seen it used as a fourth - fifth turn finisher (with a lucky draw) in casual matches.

Oh, and it can be a great draw spell for you, too. It's just a very solid, versatile card. I give it four stars. .

109702: Squall Line.author: BongRipper420
109702: Squall Line.text_parsed:
If nothing else, this is direct damage at instant speed in green, which doesn't happen very often. The fact that it happens to be removal is a nice bonus as well.

I have a mono-green Elf ramp deck where this is an easy finisher. I can't count how many times I've ended games (1v1 and large multiplayer alike) with a Squall Line for ridiculous damage, while I've been safely out of range of this weapon thanks to a Wellwisher or two. I love this card, even if it has a tendency to suck the fun out of certain games.

Also, I honestly prefer this over Hurricane always. Yeah, it costs more to cast, but I find the instant speed is more than worth it. Plus green shouldn't have any trouble coming up with that extra mana.

109702: Squall Line.author: Discoduck
109702: Squall Line.text_parsed: I love the few green cards that deal damage to all players - after all, unlike red, green has some very good life gain cards, meaning you can ramp into a massive this after using stuff like Nourishing Shoal or Lifegift to give yourself a pretty big buffer. Not the strongest strategy out there, but a fun way to win in green that isn't "I attack you with big stompy X," so I like it.

109706: Harmonic Sliver.author: Evil_Tactics
109706: Harmonic Sliver.text_parsed:
I'm surprised at the general low rating. This is one of the best sideboard slivers ever, and it can be played outside of a sliver deck. It turns all your slivers into Esper's worst nightmare, and it kills Oblivion Ring. Especially in casual or extended, having one of these in a sliver deck is essential, especially if you have Homing Slivers to tutor for it when needed most. Worst case scenario, your opponents aren't using any artifacts or enchantments at all, its a 1/1 sliver for 3.

Plus it's a very mean combo with Enchanted Evening, or even Mycosynth Lattice if you're desperate enough.

***

@dybeck

It would be most problematic to deal with Harmonic Sliver if Crystalline Sliver is already on the battlefield. It would take Wrath of God and similar board wipers to deal with that kind of army. Of course, I have used emergency Ghostways before to evade them...

@nemesis0026

No, the first Harmonic Sliver that you cast and successfully enters the battlefield will trigger the effect right away. This is also mentioned in the card's rulings list.

109706: Harmonic Sliver.text_parsed: As others have pointed out, the reason for the low rating is entirely because of the lack of "you may" in the card text. 109707: Spell Burst.author: GrimjawxRULES
109707: Spell Burst.text_parsed:
This card feels like it was made to counter the famous 0-cmc suspend cards from Time Spiral set, however it also deals quite nicely with the Pact cycle from Future Sight.
Taking a broader view, this card also deals quite nicely with Lotus and the moxes.

Also works pretty well against 1-cmc spells, as countering a 1-cmc spell with this corresponds with having a Counterspell with a manacost of . That being said, this card obviously weakens the higher cmc your opponents' spells have, however the buyback ability can still make is a real pain to deal with later in the game (i.e. you're at 8 lands and your opponent topdecks a 4-cmc spell).

4/5

Oh yeah, could this be used to repeatedly counter an opponent's commander in EDH? :)

109707: Spell Burst.author: Tayren
109707: Spell Burst.text_parsed:
My Favorite Commander counterspell.

Goes in pretty much any blue commander deck I make. Not game-breakingly powerful by any means, but I always hate stacking countermagic in my EDH Decks, and anything that can counter 3-4 or even more spot removals over the course of the game is incredible in the format.

Yes, it costs 6 to counter a Doom Blade with the buyback, which is by no means efficient, but the fact that you can do it again makes it well worth a slot.

3. Easily reusable with Urza lands and artifact mana.

EDIT: After a bit of testing, yeah this card is kinda nuts. I find it pretty easy to get a counter-lock that can only be broken by opponent's counterspells or uncounterable stuff.

109710: Strangling Soot.author: ParadOxymoron
109710: Strangling Soot.text_parsed: This is the runt of the Time Spiral allied colors cycle. Every single other card got played. Mystical Teachings defined the format (with the help of Teferi) for a year. Momentary Blink was a very powerful deck through to the Lorwyn years, Ancient Grudge was the defining artifact removal spell in Extended for basically the entire span of its time as a legal Extended card, and even Thrill of the Hunt got played in Zoo to help with the mirror. This, however? This card is just crap. I wish it had been a more exciting form of removal – perhaps if it had said 2 toughness instead of 3, but cost 1B/3R instead of 2B/5R, it could have been a sort of Black/Red Threads of Disloyalty, serving as an answer to tiny creatures, and found its competitive niche there. Alas, some things are not meant to be.

109715: Riftwing Cloudskate.author: ClockworkSwordfish
109715: Riftwing Cloudskate.text_parsed: I don't know what it is about this guy, but it's much more useful than it seems on paper. Early on, it's not too hard to invest a couple mana in; three turns later, after your opponent and possibly even you have forgotten about it, boom, haste-having flier AND (more usefully) you get to bounce something to either make them waste mana replaying it or clear the way for your ground troops. Lategame, when mana is less tight, you can hardcast it as a sorcery-speed Boomerang with a free flier. Between this and Skyreach Manta, I love flying devilfish.

109717: Ghostflame Sliver.author: Atali
109717: Ghostflame Sliver.text_parsed:
@ Torturing101
@Condor_96

Player 1 casts All Is Dust
Player 2 casts Quick Sliver in response to AiD
Quick Sliver resolves (Sliver spells have flash)
Player 2 casts Ghostflame Sliver in response to AiD
Ghostflame Sliver resolves (All Slivers are colorless)
All Is Dust Resolves, Slivers take note of the event, but are unimpressed.

But the only real reason to run this in a sliver deck is if you're running All Is Dust yourself (certainly not a bad idea).

Also, All Is Dust shouldn't be used as a reset button like that, that's really not it's best use. If you're playing it (seven mana sorcery) defensively, you're losing. It's a superpowerful finisher spell, akin to Plague Wind and Decree of Pain.

109717: Ghostflame Sliver.author: manaderp
109717: Ghostflame Sliver.text_parsed: I know I'm late here, but in the interest of not confusing new players who happen to read this: You could in fact flash in a Quick Sliver in response to All is Dust, let it resolve, then cast this one before All is Dust resolves, because whenever something resolves the active player gets priority (meaning all players, in turn order) have a chance to take further actions. This is pretty basic stuff, guys.

109721: Paradox Haze.author: Mode
109721: Paradox Haze.text_parsed:
I second that - indeed a very versatile Johnny card.
I'm glad it only costs , this mid-game cost is about what a card has to cost for an effect meant to have a use when combined with other cards only. And it only costs a single blue mana, which allows spashing with other colors without getting notable color problems, another upside that doesn't restrict combo range.
The best part is that you even get to decide whether you punish an opponent with a further upkeep (if you run cards like Black Vise or Ebony Owl Netsuke for example), or profit yourself from a second one for you (e.g. if you have an Mirror-Sigil Sergeant or Ivory Crane Netsuke)
109721: Paradox Haze.text_posted:
I second that - indeed a very versatile [autocard]Johnny[/autocard] card.
I'm glad it only costs [2U], this mid-game cost is about what a card has to cost for an effect meant to have a use when combined with other cards only. And it only costs a single blue mana, which allows spashing with other colors without getting notable color problems, another upside that doesn't restrict combo range.
The best part is that you even get to decide whether you [i]punish an opponent[/i] with a further upkeep (if you run cards like [autocard]Black Vise[/autocard] or [autocard]Ebony Owl Netsuke[/autocard] for example), or [i]profit yourself[/i] from a second one for you (e.g. if you have an [autocard]Mirror-Sigil Sergeant[/autocard] or [autocard]Ivory Crane Netsuke[/autocard])

109721: Paradox Haze.author: remnant_phoenix
109721: Paradox Haze.text_parsed:
So many ways to use this card! Combos off of ANYTHING where good things happen during your upkeep OR bad things happen during your opponent's upkeep. Once you have one or two of these on yourself, drop Braids, Conjurer Adept and abuse her power, or throw one of these on your opponent after they've put Lord of the Pit in play.

One of my favorite decks is built around suspending Reality Strobes and Deep-Sea Krakens and playing these. Let the bounce-fest begin and the big unblockables jump into play fast.

Yes, I'm a Johnny. Is it too obvious?

109721: Paradox Haze.author: awalltoo
109721: Paradox Haze.text_parsed:
I love this card and what it allows, but I'm sort of surprised that this is uncommon. If a card was going to let me do something as dramatic have a second upkeep, I'd have expected it to be rare. Doubly so for the fact that this card also introduced the concept of "Enchant Player." Making it uncommon certainly leads to lots of fun in limited, but the card seems constructed-worthy enough that it'd have seen play anyway even at rare.

The Johnny in me is thrilled to see a card like this show up at a low enough rarity to see play frequently. I'm just surprised that R&D let it happen.
109721: Paradox Haze.text_posted:
I love this card and what it allows, but I'm sort of surprised that this is uncommon.  If a card was going to let me do something as dramatic have a second upkeep, I'd have expected it to be rare.  Doubly so for the fact that this card also introduced the concept of "Enchant Player."  Making it uncommon certainly leads to lots of fun in limited, but the card seems constructed-worthy enough that it'd have seen play anyway even at rare.

The Johnny in me is thrilled to see a card like this show up at a low enough rarity to see play frequently. I'm just surprised that R&D let it happen.

109721: Paradox Haze.author: JaxsonBateman
109721: Paradox Haze.text_parsed:
Awesome in just a huge variety of decks. Many, many decks have useful "at the beginning your upkeep" triggers, so doubling them for 3 mana is just darn nice.

Seems like it'd go pretty well with the Shrine enchantments, as well as other things. I've seen it used quite effectively with the recycling suspend cards (2 Hazes mean they go off every turn, 4 Hazes mean that every 3 turns you get 5 uses of a single spell!), and personally I've had success with it in a WUG token deck. Heck, you could even use it with Sen Triplets in a multiplayer game to play cards from multiple players' hands. ^^

109721: Paradox Haze.author: blurrymadness
109721: Paradox Haze.text_parsed:
@molly_llama
That only sort of works; in the sense that the cumulative upkeep will get huge quickly. The mana will still dissipate between steps, so (for example)

Braids has 0 counters and you have a paradox haze out:
-Upkeep
-CU on Braids adds a counter and 1 mana
-Paradox haze kicks in at end of upkeep
-Mana drains out of your pool
-CU on BRaids adds a counter and 2 mana

You have 2 mana; not 3. This means that you'll get lots of counters, but it doesnt stack the way you're implying.

109733: Momentary Blink.author: Kontrah
109733: Momentary Blink.text_parsed: @Sleazebag: Short answer: Yes. If you blink the creature during your turn, it can't attack or tap unless it has haste. If you blink the creature during opponent's turn, it's like playing a creature with flash; it could attack or tap next turn.
109733: Momentary Blink.text_posted: @Sleazebag:  Short answer: Yes.  If you blink the creature during your turn, it can't attack or tap unless it has haste.  If you blink the creature during opponent's turn, it's like playing a creature with flash; it could attack or tap next turn.

109733: Momentary Blink.author: Raja_of_Dune
109733: Momentary Blink.text_parsed: I wondered why tokens couldn't come back to the battlefield with this card.  I knew tokens cease existing outside the battlefield because of rule 704.5d.  But that is a state-based action, and SBA's aren't checked during the resolution of an ability.  But for those wanting to know, the rule that applies to this card for tokens is 110.5g.
109733: Momentary Blink.text_posted: I wondered why tokens couldn't come back to the battlefield with this card.  I knew tokens cease existing outside the battlefield because of rule 704.5d. 109741: Ivory Giant.author: Equinox523
109741: Ivory Giant.text_parsed: Maybe one of the reasons people don't like this card is due to the fact that it has the potential to eat up the turn 1 aggressive 2/1 drop with no visible benefit until many turns later. But the ability to tap down all of your opponents creatures for a white weenie alpha strike is enticing, and could be very interesting if you plan around it. Also note that this, and all suspend creatures, are immune to Wrath of God while hanging out in the aether, and this giant can be a powerful way to swing a game in your favor, even if your opponent plays creatures post-Wrath.
109741: Ivory Giant.text_posted: Maybe one of the reasons people don't like this card is due to the fact that it has the potential to eat up the turn 1 aggressive 2/1 drop with no visible benefit until many turns later. Also note that this, and all suspend creatures, are immune to [autocard]Wrath of God[/autocard] while hanging out in the aether, and this giant can be a powerful way to swing a game in your favor, even if your opponent plays creatures post-Wrath.

109751: Ancient Grudge.author: holgir
109751: Ancient Grudge.text_parsed:
Ancient Grudge is a tournament sideboard staple which sees no play in casual because pure artifact destruction is too narrow if you can't cycle it (Scrap), or don't build your deck around it (Thran Forge or Neurok Transmuter) or have no spellshaper or other discard outlet handy.
That said, it is a good card at what it does.

109752: Jaya Ballard, Task Mage.author: SleetFox
109752: Jaya Ballard, Task Mage.text_parsed:
I love Jaya for the following reasons:

1.) Power. Her card is very powerful, being capable of doing very good things, all for a fairly reasonable up-front price. Pyroblast is a fun card, but usually not worth playing. However, the fact that you can also play Incinerate or Inferno with the same card makes it worth playing, and when you're up against a blue deck, it just gets better.
2.) Flavor. This card represents a Planeswalker before she became a Planeswalker. The card is very similar to a Planeswalker before Planeswalker cards even existed. That's one of the most awesome parallels between lore and set design I've ever seen from this game.
3.) Character. Jaya Ballard quotes are among my favorite flavor texts. I wish she were on more burn spells, but alas, Chandra Nalaar is taking the spotlight now.
4.) Art. Honestly, look at her. I mean really. Mrawr.

109752: Jaya Ballard, Task Mage.author: JaxsonBateman
109752: Jaya Ballard, Task Mage.text_parsed:
She's not exactly a 'one drop Jace killer' given that she costs 3. =P

But I can't believe I only just found this card. It's pretty nice - there's no card advantage on its own (though the third ability is likely to generate advantage), but the versatility is awesome. Turning any card into an anti-blue vindicate is good. Turning any card into a Volcanic Hammer is good. Turning any card into a Bloodfire Colossus effect is good.

In terms of comboing, I recently put her in a deck that, besides other thing, has Basilisk Collar + various pingers (4 Cunning Sparkmage, 4 Goblin Sharpshooter and 3 Niv-Mizzet), and she offers just another way to turn that Basilisk Collar into ensured creature removal.

Certainly wouldn't be the worst card to have late in a casual game when you're top decking. Oh, I got a land? Actually, I'd prefer a Lightning Bolt/board sweep.

109752: Jaya Ballard, Task Mage.author: Missile_Penguin
109752: Jaya Ballard, Task Mage.text_parsed:
Each Time Spiral card was an homage to at least one previously printed card.

The card represents Jaya Ballard (http://wiki.mtgsalvation.com/article/Jaya_Ballard), a player favorite for her humorous and sadistically to-the-point flavor text quotations throughout Ice Age block. For her card, she can spellshape three different spells she was quoted on: Pyroblast, Incinerate, and Inferno; this spellshaper turns any card in your hand into one!

After the events of Ice Age, she ascended into a planeswalker and helped found the pyromancer academy which Chandra trained at. This card represents her snatched out of her timeline prior to ascending to planeswalker status. Despite the seeming similarity between her three ability layout to modern Planeswalker cards, Wizards of the Coast has stated numerous times that this card was not a precursor to them.
109752: Jaya Ballard, Task Mage.text_posted:
[b]Each [i]Time Spiral[/i] card was an homage to at least one previously printed card.[/b]

The card represents Jaya Ballard (http://wiki.mtgsalvation.com/article/Jaya_Ballard), a player favorite for her humorous and sadistically to-the-point flavor text quotations throughout Ice Age block. For her card, she can spellshape three different spells she was quoted on: [autocard]Pyroblast[/autocard], [autocard]Incinerate[/autocard], and [autocard]Inferno[/autocard]; this spellshaper turns any card in your hand into one! 

After the events of [i]Ice Age[/i], she ascended into a planeswalker and helped found the pyromancer academy which [autocard]Chandra[/autocard] trained at. This card represents her snatched out of her timeline prior to ascending to planeswalker status. Despite the seeming similarity between her three ability layout to modern Planeswalker cards, Wizards of the Coast has stated numerous times that this card was not a precursor to them.
